Strategic procurement at 1.3 million. We have 9.9 FTEs in here. This is again supporting the procurement for Fleets, Hits and Fire departments. One thing I want to note on the financial reporting operations, I don't know if I think I probably missed it. Financial reporting operations at 3.6 million. This is handling the Invoice reconciliations and payments for several departments including Hits, Public Works, Fire Departments and Planning as well as the payment on the Energy Management, that is the electricity and natural gas bills that we have to pay as well as the service chargeback processing including the EMS Billing. That is all in this revolving fund. Moving on to the next slide. Slide five again. I'm just going to go briefly again. You all know what we do in the Finance Department. This is the major services in the Finance departments is managing the Citywide Debt and Capital Management budgeting forecasting, citywide Energy Contracts, financial Reporting and Auditing, grants Management Oversight, Disaster Recovery as you're all aware, as well as the Cdwat procurement. Next slide on the statutory requirements for service delivery. I want to stress out, we do have to comply with the statute requirements for what we do in the Finance Department, that is from ensuring compliance with the Texas Tax Code and Propositions One and H to make sure that the city present a balanced budget in accordance with state law and financial policies. We also have to follow the federal and state compliance, including the procurement law that we have to out comply and also completion of the annual financial and single audit, again to be in compliance with the state and federal laws. So again, any mismanagement of these functions will be impacting the cities tremendously from uninformed decisions from you all and the mayor's procurement failure that will impact the surface delivery and city operations, to claw back the federal funds and even to defaulting of the city debt. So it is important for us in our function in the finance departments to comply with all of these laws for the sustainability of the city's operations. So let's start looking into the numbers at this point. I know we don't have the slides. So again, slide seven. So on the General fund, again, we have 2.1 billion. The bulk of the property tax and sales tax is in the Finance Department's business area, $2.1 billion general fund in fiscal year 23, which is 51.5 million higher compared to the fiscal year 22 estimates. That is about 2.5% increase. I know we've went a great deal in the budget overview on the property tax and sales tax as we saw it initially. Again, to keep in mind, property tax and sales tax alone is comprised about 98.7% of the financial revenues in the revolving fund. We have about 7.5 million in here, but again, this is a surface chargeback so it is essential revenues as we recover the cost of providing financial services to this department. So the next slide, slide eight is going through the details again. Again, as we mentioned, our property tax is at $1.28 billion, reflect an increase of 48.9 million compared to fiscal year 22 estimates. Again, we've covered this before, our sales tax revenues is at $807,000,000, which is assuming no growth at this point. Again, we continue to monitor. We've seen some upticks in fiscal year 2022, but again, with so many uncertainties and even going through the consultant review, we felt that it's probably best to just keep it flat at this point because of those uncertainties in the inflations for fiscal year 23 budget for mixed beverage taxes at 20.7 million reflects about $570,000 increase from fiscal year 22 estimates. Next slide, which is slide nine, this is the expenditure site on the again, a combined budget that we have in fiscal year 23 is about 28.3 million. 20.8 million is for General Fund and 7.5 of that is for thank you revolving Fund. So we'll go through the details in the next slide. Slide ten thank you. So, slide ten, this is just again the compositions on the general fund for the personnel versus non personnel. Again, personnel compress about 76% in the general fund of 15.8 million and 24% or 5 million is the non personnel of which if you look at the pie charts on the right that comprise of billing collections about 1.3 million. So that is the billing collections where we pay for the Harris County tax office for the property tax collected. We also have an audit, auditing contracts 1.6 million. So our fiscal year 22 current budget at this point with those adjustments at 19 million. So now moving on to the incremental increases to come up with our fiscal year 23. So again, that city council surplus is a one time adjustment. So we took it out this budget, it does include funding for ten new positions. So I did ask for funding for ten new positions in my departments. This is to help assisting the Strategic Procurement Grants offer site and also capital Management. Again, with this federal money that we have, we need more streamlined process and help in those procurement divisions as well as the Grants offer site. So those contractual mandate increases about 621,000. So in total our budget increased by 1.6 million. So that comprised about 8.6% from the fiscal year 22 current budget. So those are the details that increase decrease from fiscal year 22 to fiscal year 23 expenditures budget. Next slide. Again, I mentioned this briefly when we go through the net change again, our budget includes for both General fund and revolving fund, includes funding for health benefits, pension contributions and the 3% hope pay increases. Again in general fund it does include funding for ten new employees, new positions to keep up with the increasing workload. This is dealing with the Strategic procurement and the grants management as well as the capital and debt functions revolving fund. Again, this is just to provide funding for financial procurement and accounts payable receivable support to hit Fleet and Fire, as well as the energy management. Again, it's very straightforward. I think that's the end of my presentations and I'm open for any questions. Thank you, council Member Abby Cayman. Thank you, Director Emo. Again, I just wanted to thank you for all the work you and your team do, and even in other efforts that we as council are undertaking, we come to you and you're always willing to help us and support us. So thank you for making our jobs a lot easier. I'm going to be asking this question of every department. Given the significant budget constraints that the city continues to face, are there priority items that your department is not going to be getting in this budget? If not be getting yeah, thank you for asking that question. So, one thing's first. With the Pandemic and a lot of the grants funding we have, the first party I ask for the mayor, is to make sure that we have enough resources to carry those reporting and making sure that federal monies are spent in compliance. So I am gracious enough to get those decisions funded, as you see in this budget, and that includes the procurement groups. Again, we handle city wide functions in here from the grants offer side and the procurement. So I think I don't have anything else at this point. Again, it may change because, again, we've talked about great resignations and competitiveness with the market. And I think, again, this is happening in all across the board, that everybody's seeing that. And so I may come then. But at this point, since this is the start of the fiscal year, I have been graciously granted those funding. Thank you, Council Member Ed Pollard. Thank you, Mayor Pro Tim. And sorry if these questions were asked earlier, but I just wanted to kind of get a general overview for the public on just how financially sound stable we are currently. I know we throw out a lot of numbers and this is kind of a high level overview, but for the general person that's just tuning in, would you say that the city right now is financially sound? Yes. So I just want to point out, so for credit rating agencies to change their outlook from negative to stable is a great deal for the items that the mayor had accomplished with the pension reform and the OPEC reform. Those credit rating agencies really recognize the leadership, including you all, to managing the financials of the city of Houston. So, yes, we are currently financially sound. Are there any specific shortfalls that you see that we need to be aware of? It depends on where we go, where the path we are moving forward at this point. And I think that's why I stress enough about preserving this fund balance, because we can be in the path that we should. Has the administration identified specific allocations regarding the ARPA dollars that will be coming in that we need to be aware of. So I know I mentioned to you about we have $160,000,000 of ARPA funding in here. And I know Mayor mentioned about the use of the ARPA dollars for the revenue losses in the next year. I know there's other projects that have been presented and I think you all have seen it as well. The ones if Houston, for example, is part of the ARPA fundings and I can give you the list, I think we have the ARPA website already open, so we can give you those details. Well, I want to thank you again as well for your leadership and your entire team. Thank you for all the hard work and the long nights. We all appreciate it. So thank you very much. Thank you. It means a lot. Council Member David Robinson. Thank you, Mayor Protem. And following on the line of my two colleagues with their last questions, I just want to say thank you for everything you're doing. I think this is a good wrap up to the last two days where we've heard from you, from the mayor in particular. And I know a moment ago when you were acknowledging your staff, who we all feel very strongly about, great job, everyone. You mentioned Vernita Jones, who was not in the chamber at the time, and Vernita is here. So I just wanted to call particular attention to her because she does a great job across the street taking care of us and our budgets for all our people. And to the point about impact of the great resignation, I know she's had a lot of work to do for a number of our offices. So I just wanted to ask you one follow up question to that. I don't know if she heard it. When she was absent, did you mean that you were zeroing out her budget? Is that right? I find that hard to believe. No. Okay. All right, thanks. Council Member Sally Alcorn. Thank you. And good for you for getting the ten new positions. I know you need them. In the big book, you mentioned as one of your performance measures getting in compliance with our financial policies 100%. I just see that we're out of compliance on just two of them. One has to do with internal controls and one on our credit rating. Can you explain a little bit further about how we're going to come in compliance with that? I think on the structurally balanced budget stuff, it's in progress, but those two were out of compliance. So can you talk about that? Yeah. So keep in mind when we have that and we keep our bar high, which is good. When we did the financial policy, I think it was based on fiscal year 2014, if I'm not mistaken. And a lot happened from fiscal year 2014 to now. So there was a time when we did get downgraded and I can't remember which one. And I think, like I said, we were having a negative outlook and so now we're moving back up. So we are in the right path just by that change from negative to stable. Let's start the change of the credit rating does not come overnight. So it takes some steps because they want to make sure how you run in that year and then the next year then they will change it. And so now the fact that we change from the negative to stable is good. So the next hope is with all this preserve fund balance, hopefully we would get those additional increase in the credit rating so that we can go back to the compliance compared to fiscal year 14. On the risk assessment, there was part of our budget reductions, to be honest with you, with the internal audit, again, during fiscal year 14 to now, a lot of things happen. The economy landscape has changed. So there was budget reductions on the internal audit, so there was out of compliance. So we are going back to see what we can do to put it back in the compliance state. Okay, great. And I have some questions on specific line items within general government and you're the appropriate person to send those to correct? I mean, you can do that. I can tell you the dollars on what so some of the operating questions are probably will have to defer, but okay, we'll do those in writing. Thank you. Thank you. And there are no other council members in queue. And I made these comments yesterday. The City of Houston budget is made up by the administration, you and your staff and the mayor and presented to us and we make amendments to it. But our final vote is either yes or no. We either accept it or we reject it. I think this budget is in the best shape of any budget I dealt with in my nine years here. And it's because of you and your team and the diligence that we put forward a year ago when we saw sales tax revenue and a lot of our revenue gone down and we made some specific budgetary cuts and we see the good of those. So thanks for your leadership, always enjoy working with you and your deputy directors, mr. Jones and Ms. Dabowski, and your entire team. You all do a great job day in and day out in a tough environment and thanks for everything you do. And I do believe this budget process is hopefully going to be one of the smoothest ones we see because of some of the pain that you saw coming and you made adjustments, you and your team. So thanks for that. We do have three virtual public speakers. The first is Saba Blanding star Six. Again, Ms. Blanding. Star six. There you go. Yes. Okay. There I'm unmuted. Can you hear me okay? Yes. Wonderful. I have a question kind of two sides of probably the same coin. You mentioned the high number of Vacancies going into the budget cycle. Why is retention an issue for your department beyond the great resignation and how can we improve it? And then kind of alongside that and maybe kindred to what council member came in, asked earlier. I'm just really curious, in a perfect world, how many employees does your department need ideally? Like what would be the perfect number and what type of kind of similar to this, what type of pay increases would there be ideally? So I have a more pragmatic question about Vacancies and retention and improving it and then just kind of I would like to know the ideal number of employees so we can kind of know the difference between what's happening and what is needed. Okay, so it's an interesting question. Let's start with the Vacancies at this point. So we are in the general fund departments, and you've gone through the budget presentations with our limited revenue sources. And so we have to continuously looking for efficiencies and process improvements in the finance and city department. Citywide, what happened with the Pandemic? I think it changed and I think you probably know this too, it changed the landscape of the global mindset of employees and employer too, right? So some private sectors can provide those flexibilities that we don't at the city of Houston, right? Because the work is different. We have people who have to be here meeting citizens. And the pay the market study, again, it's hard to compete with the private sectors. Of course, when you do a market study, you compare with the same government, municipal employees. And so we continuously looking at that. And of course it's a vicious cycle, if I can say. The more work you do, the more burned out you are, and then the more you are looking for other position elsewhere. And so that's what happened. Retentions at the same time, because you don't have enough people and you are overworked pay increases, an ideal number of people. And I can go back on the previous years when we don't have any all of these cuts and to see what those numbers are, you're probably looking at back in 2010 or I mean 2008, if anything. Right. And I have to look at this FTEs number. But those are difficult situations to handle at this point, especially when you deal with the competitiveness with the market. Thank you, jason Oliver, before, there has been conversation about unmet needs I'm really kind of interested in because some departments come up and they say we're not able to do X, Y and Z because of the limitations or because of the cuts that we've made. And I'm less clear on how that is working with the finance department. So I'm interested and I'm curious about these kind of unmet needs for finance. And then you had talked about a market study comparing to municipal employees. You said that we had kind of leveled out legal. And I'm wondering if we are competitive if we're looking at municipal finance employees. And I wanted to circle back to the outcomes based budgeting because I'm interested in if it's possible, like will you modify your you had talked about changing your budget calendar during the last presentation, so I'm wondering if you'll be modifying it to better incorporate public input. For example, many cities hold public workshops both before and after a proposed budget is released to really get the community knowledgeable about what's in there and make sure that their priorities are included. So three things. First is unmet needs. Second, competitive based on municipal employees. And then third, about modifying the budget calendar as we shift to outcomes based budgeting. Can you say the first one again? Unmet needs. Unmet needs. Okay, thank you. So again, I mentioned in some of my slide on the finance departments, what we do in the finance department is a lot of that is actually compliance with the state and federal regulations. Right? You're talking about the procurement, talking about, again, the debt management making sure that we are not mismanaging those and you don't want to have any stations when we are at the default. At this point, the budget, which is again is governed in the state and local policies and again the grants disaster recovery. What we do is essentially essential to the city. And so I cannot say that I would not be meeting those functions because it's a must in that sense. So, yeah, I cannot say that I cannot meet any demands because the function that we do are directly affecting out of compliance of the city to the state and local charter. So the impact is maybe, I don't know, maybe a late payment if that is the case. But of course it bites you back because then you have to pay late fees. For example, going back to your comment, it's not unmet needs, but I probably will have a delay if I don't have enough people in the procurements. But you don't want to have a wrong product being delivered or you don't want to have a wrong scope being written. So again, those expertise in my area is very crucial because what we do is going to be affecting the entire city's operations. So I cannot stress enough the city wide functions that our departments handles. So the last comment you have is the outcome based budgeting we will have. And I think Mr. Jones had mentioned to you we do have the Plan Houston process, and I think the input that we want from the public is the priorities. Exactly what do you want to see the city spend the dollars? The outcome based budgeting is just a vision on how it's going to look like. But I think the key that you are trying to get is the input of the public for those priorities. And I believe that is already in place. But I can double check, but those are the priorities that need some input from the public. Thank you. Next speaker is Mr. Doug Smith. Thank you. I just want to go back to a question I asked earlier that didn't get answered. We received $300 million of ARPA funds and we're going to get another 300 million. And the first 300 million was used last year. And then this coming budget, if I understand correctly, but you're addressing the budget gap does not take into consideration the next 300 million that we're going to receive. So that's one question. And then is there somewhere how you calculated the property tax? Because when I look at the projected increase, it's 3.9% over 2022. And I thought the state law and I don't know the state law, but I thought the state law mandated a three and a half percent increase. So I would like to see how that calculation was done. And finally, in the raw data under other interfund services, which I understand you explained well, there's revenues of $7,400,000. And where does that revenue appear? If it does appear in page 625 where you list all of your revenues, those are my questions. Okay. So I think correct me if I'm wrong if I get it right, your questions. The ARPA dollar that we are receiving or to be received is $607,000,000. About $303,000,000 has been received last May. Another 303,000,000 will be received sometimes this month. This includes the allocations of ARPA of 160,000,000 at this point. That came from the first tranche, which is $303,000,000. Great. Yes. Thank you. That's what I thought. And the next 300 million, you did not take that into consideration when you talked about addressing the budget gap. You said that you didn't include that in what the proposed gap might be. Is that a correct statement? So the next tranche, again, we have the one safe Houston. We have other stuff that has already been included in the ARPA. And I know I included projected gap for fiscal year 24, with the hope is to also use the ARPA money then. But again, that will be from the second tranche. Correct me if I'm wrong. ARPA funds can be used until December 31, 2023. 424. Got it. So 24. Okay. For us, yes. The second questions you have is on, I believe is it on the property tax calculations? Yes. Because you're showing a projected 3.9% increase. And I thought that new state law mandated a three and a half percent increase. And I just like to understand how that plays against our own property tax cap. So I know our proposed budget is including the 4.28% increase of the CPI, but remember, we also have the 90 million on the Prop H. And I can go back to you again to reconcile the 3.97% versus the 4.23 of the CPI number, but some of that could be from the Prop H. Okay, well, okay. What about the state cap is three. And a half percent. How does that play into this? I will have to get back to you on those details on the calculations. I think there's also some other annexations maybe included in the fiscal year 22 budget. Again, annexation is only when it's available and only for twelve months. You don't use annexations every single year. So maybe some other stuff in the fiscal year 22 estimates. Just a reminder of any additional questions. If you want to send to District E at houstontx Gov, we will answer them and get back to you. A reminder to the council members council members should submit any department budget workshop questions in a Word document and we'll upload that to SharePoint and departments have been directed to provide responses within 48 hours of the conclusion of their presentation. Department responses will also be uploaded on SharePoint and give us two minutes and we'll transition. And my apologies to Chief Pena, Chief West and Ms. McHenry for the delay. I'm sure your presentation will be worth it. So thank you. We will transition and Vice Chair Ed Pollard will be sitting here two minutes.
